Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Robust Indoor Localization System for Mobile Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide accurate indoor location services to users via existing mobile electronic devices like smartphones, tablets and laptops. This technology will bring many of the applications powered by satellite-based positioning systems like navigation, tracking and location-based advertising to indoor markets. We propose using a hybrid ultrasound and RF-based beaconing system to enable sub-meter location accuracy within large GPS-denied environments. Our approach is unique in that it is compatible with current smartphones by simply downloading an app. The system uses an infrastructure comprised of beacons, which can be powered through indoor solar energy-harvesting instead of requiring expensive AC wiring. Accurate indoor location-aware mobile applications can enhance applications ranging from retail and manufacturing all the way to building navigation, asset tracking and aiding the visually impaired.

The proposed project aims to develop a robust localization platform which can localize off-the-shelf devices like smartphones and tablets as well as low-cost RF tags to better than 1 meter of accuracy in indoor locations that do not have access to GPS. Current indoor localization technologies for smartphones often fall short in terms of accuracy, especially in highly dynamic environments with obstructions. Our system utilizes energy harvesting beacons with an array of speakers to transmit time-of-flight ranging signals in the near-ultrasound spectrum. These signals can be recorded and demodulated in software by commodity smartphones, while being inaudible to humans. The research in this phase will aim to develop the methods and technologies required to scale this localization technology so that it can support large facilities like airports and convention centers that would require tens to hundreds of beacons. This involves the development of scalable multiple access protocols for ultrasound communication, networking protocols for synchronization and data collection, inertial sensor fusion algorithms for robust and accurate localization and APIs for app integration by third parties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Yodel Labs is a company specializing in indoor localization technologies with an emphasis on mobile device solutions. The company was founded to commercialize a ground breaking new localization system that enables highly accurate localization of off-the-shelf smartphones and tablets. This system is called the Acoustic Location Processing System (ALPS) and uses a combination of ultrasound ranging and sensor fusion techniques to achieve a localization error of <25cm (90th percentile), even in cluttered environments. It is a beacon-based system, where time synchronized beacons emit both Bluetooth, as well as ultrasound ranging signals that are imperceptible to humans, but detectable by mobile devices. ALPS measures the Time of Flight (TOF) of the ultrasound signals to calculate the ranges to nearby beacons and the location of the mobile device. It employs advanced filtering, as well as inertial and optionally visual sensor fusion techniques to achieve industry leading accuracy, robustness and acquisition time. The system is scalable from small single-room installations to large buildings, such as airports, factories and event venues. It supports an unbounded number of mobile devices being localized simultaneously without affecting system performance, is self-contained, connection-less and privacy preserving. The beacons are cost-effective and easy to install, each providing coverage of up to 10,000 sq ft of open space and can be solar powered by nearby light fixtures, eliminating the need for expensive wiring. The combination of high accuracy, compatibility with virtually all current smartphones and tablets through mobile software frameworks, cost effective installation and infinite scalability in terms of the number of mobile devices it supports, as well as the amount of beacons in a deployment, make it an ideal platform for the next generation of location based applications.

During Phase I of our SBIR grant we were addressing several key goals to determine the technical and commercial feasibility of our indoor localization system ALPS. These goals were:

1. To develop advanced location filtering techniques to improve the accuracy and robustness of the system.

2. To develop methods to scale ALPS deployments to commercial building size scale.

3. To develop a software framework and API for iOS and Android devices.

In addition to these primary goals, we researched the applicability of ALPS for newly emerging mobile Augmented Reality (AR) applications.

We were successfully in reaching all of our proposed goals and have developed a system which features industry leading accuracy and robustness by fusing Visual Inertial Odometery (VIO) and high precision ultrasound ranging. ALPS is infinitely scalable in both the amount of simultaneous users due to its broadcast, one-way communication architecture. Likewise, it is infinitely scalable in terms of coverage area by tiling ultrasound beacon transmissions so that there is no overlap of signals in both time and space simultaneously. Our iOS and Android frameworks allow the usage of our technology on the vast majority of current smartphones and tablets.

The recent emergence of mobile AR for smartphones and tablets is a promising application for ALPS, as the system can provide high accuracy global localization in order to support a persistent, highly scalable, multi-user AR experience. This means that AR objects can persist at the same physical locations indefinitely and can be seen by multiple users at the same locations, at the same time. Most current phone based system limit AR objects to be visible only during a single app session, by a single user. More advanced optical relocalization based systems suffer in dynamic environments and do not scale beyond small areas.
